newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power steady in thin talk.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power steady in thin talk.

text.p: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power prices held steady in relatively thin discussion Wednesday as warmth continued to blanket much of the area, brokers and marketers said.
"Although it's certainly not hot, it is pretty warm for September," one East Coast physicals trader said.
Some traders were skeptical about the continued price strength, particularly with the possibility of Hurricane Fran bringing clouds and showers to the East Coast.
Latest forecasts called for Hurricane Fran to hit South Carolina late Thursday or early Friday.
Despite the possibility of a hurricane, forecasts of normal to above-normal temperatures in the Mid-Atlantic held sway.

Next day, peak electricity prices in the Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Maryland (PJM) Interconnect power pool were said to be trading in the $23.75-24.75 range with unconfirmed reports of trades at $24.50, steady from discussion near $24.50 per megawatt hour (MWh) on Tuesday, brokers and traders said.
Peak power for the remainder of this week was said to be discussed near $24.00 from remainder of the week discussion at $23.75-24.50 on Tuesday, the sources said.
Peak electricity for the remainder of September was talked steady in the $21.20-22.40 range with one unconfirmed trade at $21.90 per MWh.
October PJM prices, under the same delivery conditions, were discussed in a range of $20.30-20.55 from a range of $20.35-20.40 per MWh on Tuesday, the brokers and marketers said.
Peak PJM power for the fourth quarter was pegged at $22.30-22.60 from a Tuesday range of $22.25-22.50 per MWh, the sources said.
-- Chris Reese, New York Power Desk 212-859-1627
